content.question: Read each question carefully. Write your response in the space provided for each part of each question. Answers must be written out in paragraph form. Outlines, bulleted lists, or diagrams alone are not acceptable and will not be scored. Sand lances of the genus Ammodytes are small fish that function as keystone organisms in several coastal ecosystems. These sand lances are prey fish that support organisms at higher trophic levels. Scientists performed experiments to examine how sand lance populations are likely to be affected by the rising temperatures and <math alttext="C O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>CO</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub></math> levels associated with climate change. Sand lance embryos typically develop and mature into adult fish at low temperatures (approximately <math alttext="5 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>5°C</mtext></math>) and stable, low <math alttext="C O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>CO</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub></math> levels (approximately <math alttext="400 microatmospheres" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>400 μatm</mtext></math>). Over the course of two years, the scientists measured the survival rate of sand lance embryos allowed to develop and mature in a laboratory at three different temperatures, <math alttext="5 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>5°C</mtext></math>, <math alttext="7 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>7°C</mtext></math>, and <math alttext="10 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>10°C</mtext></math>, with the level of <math alttext="C O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>CO</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub></math> maintained at <math alttext="400 microatmospheres" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>400 μatm</mtext></math>, <math alttext="1,000 microatmospheres" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>1,000 μatm</mtext></math>, and <math alttext="2,100 microatmospheres" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>2,100 μatm</mtext></math> for each temperature. (a) Describe the effect of increased biodiversity on the resilience of an ecosystem in a changing environment.

frqParts.text: Read each question carefully. Write your response in the space provided for each part of each question. Answers must be written out in paragraph form. Outlines, bulleted lists, or diagrams alone are not acceptable and will not be scored. Sand lances of the genus Ammodytes are small fish that function as keystone organisms in several coastal ecosystems. These sand lances are prey fish that support organisms at higher trophic levels. Scientists performed experiments to examine how sand lance populations are likely to be affected by the rising temperatures and <math alttext="C O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>CO</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub></math> levels associated with climate change. Sand lance embryos typically develop and mature into adult fish at low temperatures (approximately <math alttext="5 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>5°C</mtext></math>) and stable, low <math alttext="C O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>CO</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub></math> levels (approximately <math alttext="400 microatmospheres" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>400 μatm</mtext></math>). Over the course of two years, the scientists measured the survival rate of sand lance embryos allowed to develop and mature in a laboratory at three different temperatures, <math alttext="5 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>5°C</mtext></math>, <math alttext="7 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>7°C</mtext></math>, and <math alttext="10 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>10°C</mtext></math>, with the level of <math alttext="C O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>CO</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub></math> maintained at <math alttext="400 microatmospheres" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>400 μatm</mtext></math>, <math alttext="1,000 microatmospheres" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>1,000 μatm</mtext></math>, and <math alttext="2,100 microatmospheres" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>2,100 μatm</mtext></math> for each temperature. (a) Describe the effect of increased biodiversity on the resilience of an ecosystem in a changing environment.

(b) Justify the scientists’ selecting <math alttext="5 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>5°C</mtext></math> as the lowest temperature and <math alttext="400 microatmospheres" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>400 μatm</mtext></math> as the lowest <math alttext="C O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>CO</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub></math> level in their study of sand lance embryo survival.
(c) State a null hypothesis for the experiment.

(d) The scientists claim that a reduction in the population size of the Ammodytes sand lances will affect the stability of the entire coastal ecosystem. Provide reasoning to support the scientists’ claim.
